metadata.metaValue:
This graph is split into local compounds for organization. 

Check inside for more info on each step.

This is our "down" vector along which snow falls. 

We use it both to raycast looking for areas in snow shadows,  as well as testing against the normal of the meshes. 

Here it's set in one place.

As the last step, we mesh our particles. 

If Selective Evaluation is available, then this can offer you  a faster proxy display, and you don't pay for the mesh until it's time to render.

Here we scale our points based on the snowyness data (lighter coverings of snow mean smaller points). This data is already on our points thanks to being transfered by scatter_points. 

We also apply noise to the points. 

We then delete the points that are below a certain size to have bare areas. 

We then displace the remaining points along the mesh normal, by a fraction of their size, so the spheres sit on the surface

Does raycasting inside a for-each and returns the
fraction of the rays which found their mark. 

Also has diagnostic drawing via a terminal. Note that
it must be enabled on the outside of this compound.
First we create some geometry that can create a snow shadow.

To mesh points, we convert them to a levelset. 

A levelset, also called a signed distance field, is a type of volume data that actually represents a surface in 3D space. If each point is considered a sphere, the level set  here will create a surface enclosing the points. 

Detail size in the levelset is the main quality control here. 

By converting that back to a mesh we get our meshed particles result. This takes  some time, so we can also show the points with a sphere on each one instead with "fast proxy". To get a benefit from this you need selective evaluation.
